awd_titl_txt: Deciphering the novel link between sulfur assimilation and nitrogen fixation in methanogenic archaea
awd_abstract_narration:
Enhanced production of biofuels and crop plants is needed to meet society's ever-increasing demand for fuel, food, and feedstocks. The assimilation of atmospheric nitrogen by cells (nitrogen fixation) requires nitrogenase, an iron-sulfur enzyme found only in prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea). The overall goal of this project is to understand nitrogen fixation in a type of archaea, methanogens, and to decipher its link to sulfur assimilation. Nitrogen is a limiting nutrient in the production of crop plants, and engineering nitrogen-fixation in plants would alleviate the substantial costs and energy needed to chemically produce fertilizers currently used to overcome this limitation. Also, nitrogenase-based technology is a promising strategy to produce biofuels. The research team of high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students will use modern molecular and biochemical techniques to specifically determine the factors that control the sulfur-specific expression and assembly of nitrogenase in methanogens. To understand the scope of the effect of sulfur on nitrogen fixation by methanogens and to integrate the project with teaching, students in an upper-level lab course, taught by the PI, will use sediments from diverse sources to enrich and isolate nitrogen-fixing methanogens. Students in the lab course will gain research experience and contribute directly to the project.

All bacteria and archaea capable of nitrogen fixation (diazotrophy) contain molybdenum (Mo) nitrogenase. Some diazotrophs also contain vanadium (V) and iron (Fe) nitrogenases. The maturation of all nitrogenases requires the delivery and assembly of simple and complex iron-sulfur clusters. Thus, diazotrophs need to sense and respond to changes in available sulfur and metals during diazotrophy. In diazotrophic bacteria, the NIF system is required for the biogenesis of the iron-sulfur clusters in nitrogenase, and cysteine serves as the direct sulfur donor. Diazotrophic methanogens lack the NIF system but contain components of the ISC and SUF Fe-S cluster biogenesis systems. Methanogens can also use sulfide as an exogenous sulfur source and as the direct sulfur donor in the biogenesis of iron-sulfur clusters. Initial results with the model methanogen Methanosarcina acetivorans, which contains Mo-, V-, and Fe-nitrogenases, indicate that the exogenous sulfur source (cysteine or sulfide) causes profound differences in nitrogenase expression, inhibition of diazotrophic growth by hydrogen, and usage of ISC and SUF Fe-S cluster biogenesis systems. Thus, the hypothesis is that unlike bacteria, the assimilated sulfur source is a key determinant in the expression, assembly, and activity of nitrogenases in diazotrophic methanogens. A combination of genetic, physiological, biochemical, and transcriptomics approaches will be used with M. acetivorans to test the hypothesis. The specific objectives are to determine the effect of sulfur source on 1) diazotrophic growth and nitrogenase expression, 2) the use of ISC and SUF system components for the assembly of M. acetivorans nitrogenases, and 3) the use of hydrogenase to alleviate inhibition of nitrogenase by H2. The combined results of the project are expected to reveal the molecular factors that link sulfur assimilation to nitrogen fixation by methanogens.

por.por_cntn:
This research project explored the connection between sulfur assimilation and nitrogen fixation in the model methanogen Methanosarcina acetivorans. This microbe is environmentally important because it possesses the three known types of nitrogenase (Mo-nitrogenase, V-nitrogenase, and Fe-nitrogenase) that convert nitrogen gas into ammonia, a process essential for life on Earth. Only certain microbes, including methanogens, can perform this process. We developed a CRISPRi-dCas9 system to selectively turn off genes in M. acetivorans, which helped us discover that this microbe can utilize all three nitrogenases to fix nitrogen. We found that the production of V- and Fe-nitrogenases depends on the availability of molybdenum (Mo) and ammonia, regardless of the sulfur source. Interestingly, expression of Mo-nitrogenase is also necessary for the production of the other two nitrogenases, showing a unique connection between these enzymes. Additionally, we identified a regulatory protein that controls the expression of the genes for the V-nitrogenase and Fe-nitrogenase. 

Nitrogenases require iron-sulfur (Fe-S) clusters to function. M. acetivorans encodes the minimal components of the ISC and SUF systems used by bacteria for Fe-S cluster biogenesis. We showed that M. acetivorans contains a functional minimal ISC system. Surprisingly, removing the SUF system, which is common to all methanogens, did not impact growth or nitrogen fixation, indicating that SUF is not essential for Fe-S cluster formation. However, deleting ISC components caused growth issues during nitrogen fixation related to cysteine metabolism, not Fe-S cluster formation. Specifically, impaired cysteine metabolism impacted the production of methylsulfides, which were shown to be required for optimal nitrogen fixation by M. acetivorans. These results reveal a new connection between sulfur and nitrogen metabolism in M. acetivorans and indicate that M. acetivorans, and likely all methanogens, possess novel unknown Fe-S cluster biogenesis machinery.

Although M. acetivorans cannot use hydrogen as an energy source, our results demonstrate that it recycles hydrogen produced during nitrogen fixation using hydrogenase. This expands our understanding of the metabolic diversity of M. acetivorans and links hydrogenase usage to nitrogen fixation. Overall, our findings enhance the understanding of how methanogens like M. acetivorans contribute to the cycling of sulfur, nitrogen, and carbon on Earth. They also reveal the intricate connections between methanogenesis, sulfur metabolism, and nitrogen fixation in these microbes.

The funding for this project had broad impact on the hands-on scientific training of four postdoctoral fellows (two female), seven graduate students (four female), five undergraduate students (four female), and four high school students (two female). Results from the project were part of two Ph.D. dissertations and four undergraduate Honors Theses. Two postdoctoral researchers obtained jobs in industry, and one obtained a faculty position at an international university. The four high school students who worked on the project were recruited from the University of Arkansas Upward Bound program, which is a college preparation and access program for first-generation college students. Student researchers gained valuable experience in general experimental design, data analysis, and scientific writing, and presented results at local, regional, and international meetings. The PI incorporated findings from the project into upper-level microbiology lecture and laboratory courses taught at the University of Arkansas. Since the project used a methanogen as a model, students were exposed to new concepts and information pertaining to these lesser-known organisms, sparking the interest of a younger generation of students to research methanogens, an environmentally and biotechnologically important group of organisms.
